FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC - Maple Park, IL Fac

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Illinois Department of Agriculture and Industry Standards (Aqua)
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: AST, piping, valves, pump and containment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Aqua Ammonia S&H (Covered Process 1): 



The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of anhydrous ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff as directed.  The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.



This Facility stores and handles a 25% ammonia concentrated solution in a 30,000-gallon aboveground storage tank (AST).  The process equipment includes the AST and ancillary process piping, valves, and transfer hose.



The Facility receives aqua ammonia by a Contractor that transports the aqua ammonia with a commercial cargo tank.  The commercial cargo tank is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the aqua ammonia is transferred to the stationary AST.  The Contractor performs the transfer of aqua ammonia from the commercial cargo tank to the stationary PV.  The Facility does not own or operate the commercial cargo tank.  The Contractor is responsible for training their operators and maintaining their equipment.  At a minimum, the Contractor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT, OSHA, state and local regulatory requirements, (2) make available to the Facility and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for aqua ammonia transfer operations.  The Facility coordinates with the Contractor on Emergency Contingency procedures and will provide access to the Facility RMPr upon request by the Contractor.



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the storage of aqua ammonia in the AST.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the RMP Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the RMP Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Illinois Department of Agriculture; Industry Standards (Aqua)
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: AST, process piping, liquid pump, containment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Base Blending (Covered Process 2): 



The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of anhydrous ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff as directed.  The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.



The Base fertilizer product is produced by mixing aqua ammonia with water and other ingredients.  The process equipment is physically connected by process piping to the 30,000-gallon aqua ammonia aboveground storage tank (AST).  The process equipment includes: a stationary blender and ancillary process piping, valves, scale, and temperature gauges.  The blender is open top and does not have any storage capabilities for aqua ammonia. 



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of aqua ammonia, water, and other ingredients to the blender; (2) monitoring of mass and temperatures; and (3) transfer of product to storage.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the RMP Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the RMP Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  The fertilizer product is not subject to the RMP Rule.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC Maple Park, IL Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68.  Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the ammonia concentration in the aqua solution is less than 40% by weight and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  This electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident, and to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC (Helena) is submitting the EPA RMP as a 5-year update.



It is important to note that the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 47,953 lbs.  Although the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 47,953 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 95,906 lbs.  The reason for this is because the single aqua ammonia AST (i.e47,953 lbs) is counted a second time to account for the Base Blending process that is connected to the single stationary AST.



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  Two chemicals (i.e. anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia greater than 20% ammonia concentration) are stored and handled at quantities that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity.  Covered processes operated at this Facility include:



?    Covered Process 1: Aqua Ammonia S&H

?    Covered Process 2: Base Blending



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the two (2) covered processes.  The worst case scenario for Covered Processes 1 and 2 assumes that

all the contents in the largest (i.e. 30,000 gallons) single aboveground storage tank (AST) are released.  The release scenario assumes that the 30,000-gallon aqua ammonia AST fails and instantaneously spills the content into secondary containment that has a total containment capacity greater than 30,000 gallons when considering displacement of the other ASTs within the containment.  The resulting release is evaporation at the maximum temperature.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for Covered Process 1 assumes a rupture of a transfer hose during transfer from the commercial cargo tank to the AST.   The release occurs in the cargo tank transfer area which has a total containment capacity greater than 800 gallons.  The alternative scenario for Covered Process 2 assumes a rupture of a transfer hose or pipe during transfer from the AST to the Blender.   The release occurs in the tank farm containment which has a total containment capacity greater than 30,000 gallons when considering displacement of the other ASTs within the containment.  Mitigation by engineering and administrative controls is considered in these scenarios.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, inju

ries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or makes changes to the process. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the local LEPC and Fire Department.  



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
